abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project was
            satisfactory, sustainability is likely, and both
            performances by the Bank, and Borrower are rated
            satisfactorily. Nonetheless, several lessons drawn from the
            project suggest the following. It is once again reinforced
            that project design, particularly if directed at improving
            education quality, should be simple, with limited, and few
            components and implementing agencies, to allow enough
            flexibility to adapt to the changing requirements of a
            dynamic education system. Furthermore, design should also
            provide for effective implementation capacity on the part of
            the borrower, since weak capacity, or untrained project
            units, may lead to operational standstill as a result of
            project complexity. The introduction of educational
            innovation could fail, unless a clear understanding is
            developed between teachers, and political leaders, on the
            value of supplementary educational financing - based upon
            autonomous assessment of local weaknesses, and needs - and,
            provided that technical capacity, developed toward project
            objectives, remains within the system. In addition, quality
            improvement projects, with direct interventions in the
            operation of an educational system, should define, and
            engage institutional roles among all agencies, and the
            Ministry staff having operational responsibilities,
            regardless of whether design and preparation are
            commissioned to outside consultants.

abstracts.cdata!:
The main goals of the project are to
            help the Government of Venezuela raise the level of student
            achievement, reduce the incidence of repetition and dropout,
            and increase graduation rates of basic education through
            improvements in the quality of education and administrative
            efficiency.  Because education is moving toward being
            decentralized, another important objective of the project is
            to help states develop their own capacity for managing the
            system efficiently.  Toward these ends the project will:
            (a) increase student access to textbooks and other
            instructional materials; (b) improve teachers' skills
            and effectiveness in teaching; (c) improve the education
            management capacity of the Ministry of Education (MOE) and
            of the State Education Secretariats (SES); and (d) develop
            MOE's capacity to coordinate and formulate policies,
            monitor student learning and school quality, and identify
            bottlenecks and problems at the state and local levels in a
            timely manner.  The project consists of four components:
            (a) instructional materials development; (b) teacher
            training; (c) institutional development; and (d) studies of
            school effectiveness and educational finance and the
            identification and design of activities to improve the
            quality of education.
